body:
Thanks for the submission Prashant!
VOTE +1
Looks good to me and as it's a relatively minor change, I will merge it as a CTR.
@kenhuuu okay will do, might be a bit im just wrappedu p in some other stuff with work but this is in the back of my mind.

VOTE +1
Thanks for putting together the work! Looking forward to the rest of the changes.

Thank you for the contribution! As lazy consensus has been reached, I'll be merging this PR today if there are no further comments. 

One small note, it does look like this PR is missing a CHANGELOG entry, which I'm happy to add it after merging as CTR.

Could you check your test set up? It seems like there is a serialization error with it. 
`org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.driver.ser.SerializationException: java.io.IOException: Serializer for type org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.server.GremlinServerAuthzIntegrateTest$$Lambda$597/0x000000080074d840 not found`

@xiazcy Yeah its wrong right now, I need to do it a different way, I wasn't able to test locally due to jvm installation mismatches so I tried that blindly. I'll try to see if I can do it a different way.
@xiazcy I tried something else, hopefully it works :pray:

Thank you for the PR @gautam-nutalapati! A couple of notes on this:
- This connection logging level might be something that can affect other user's debugging workflows, so a devlist discussion post might be needed to let the community know of the proposed change
- The master branch will be for the next major release, you would need to rebase and retarget your change to 3.6-dev if you'd like to include this change in the next maintenance releases for 3.6 and 3.7. 
- Please include a CHANGELOG entry
I took a look at driver and server changes (mostly to handling of RequestMessageV4 and HttpGremlinEndpointHandler) and they LGTM.
VOTE +1. Thanks everyone for the review!

i have two general suggestions: (1) be a bit more succinct and (2) more formatting to draw the eye to stuff that matters. 

more specifically, in the name of (1), i think you could consider removing:

>  If the changes are substantial and require the attention of either providers or users then add an entry to the UPGRADE documentation found at (docs/src/upgrade).

most random PRs don't rise to this level. committers are probably better judges for what is a "substantial" change and can ask for it in review. that spares a few words. 

Another potential word saver is:

>   If there is a mailing list post that is related to this PR, then add a link to the dev list post in the description as well.

If there was a dev list post it probably has a JIRA and would be linked in there. Also, perhaps not applicable to the average random PR.

Really like the links to the dev docs and information about VOTEing as it sets the expectation that it may take time to get to being merged. Would be nice if that could be less wordy.  btw, no need to thank folks twice - saved two more words  

I don't mean to be overly focused on number of words, but if this takes too long to read, it might not have the desired effect. Maybe consider making another pass over the whole thing to see where else the same information could be conveyed with less (particularly the target branch section as that is a typical thing to get wrong). what's the minimum words that could be used to get folks to pick the right branch.

Regarding (2) i think a combination of emoji and bold text would do the trick, though I assume that a small Gremlin pic somewhere wouldn't hurt.

Thanks @rdtr for the PR! There is a couple of fixes needed in the feature tests for GLVs. 
Another note, since you've updated the feature tests, please also push the correspondingly updated GLV tests files, ie the `gremlin.cs`, `gremlin.js`, `gremlin.py`, `gremlin.go` files (should be auto generated after doing a local `mvn clean install`).
VOTE +1, also pending GLV feature test file updates (i.e. `gremlin.cs`, `gremlin.js`, `gremlin.py`, `gremlin.go`).
Good to also update `TrimLocalStep` to unsure consistent behavior.

> I don't mean to be overly focused on number of words, but if this takes too long to read, it might not have the desired effect.

I agree with this and have tried to explain the target branch in as few words as possible, but couldn't quite shorten it down anymore. I feel the need to explain our branch management strategy as it seems to be slightly different than other projects and a common source of confusion for new contributors.

> (2) more formatting to draw the eye to stuff that matters.

Also agree, but I'm limited on what I can do here based on this being a hidden comment that won't render formatting.

> same character control

done! Now they all rely on the same common method

i think there is an extensive set of changelog and upgrade docs to write up here with major removals to keep track of and new things introduced.  lots and lots of change to account for that is going to a branch with an equal amount of change. probably a good time to take stock of what was done here and document it as part of the PR.

Thanks Valentyn, this is a huge piece of work and a massive step towards simplifying TinkerPop.
LGTM VOTE +1
VOTE +1. Thanks for this great body of work!

Also, you should add an entry to the CHANGELOG.asciidoc.

I'm not that familiar with Go, but I'll have another committer that is review this PR as well.

Hi Lyndon, were you planning on merging this? If not, I can help you merge it this week. I'd prefer not to leave this PR hanging around since it might cause conflicts with other PRs (the CHANGELOG, in particular, usually causes conflicts).

I feel as though the solution you are suggesting here may affect others if they are depending on that information to be at the ERROR level. It could be considered breaking for some users. For this reason, I feel like a more complete change would be to update the behavior of how the driver responds to a close frame. I've suggested a way of doing this in [TINKERPOP-3094](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TINKERPOP-3094).

Would you be OK with closing this PR and waiting or working on a fix like the one suggested in TINKERPOP-3094?

@kenhuuu go ahead and merge it, sorry I am caught up in some stuff right now
Thank you for the improvement and added test cases, LGTM. VOTE +1

VOTE +1.

Please follow the instructions in the PR template next time for the CHANGELOG entry. I'll commit a follow-up change to make a minor adjustment so that this PR can be merged now. Thanks again for contributing.

is the bulking feature optional for the server? it feels like it should be an optimization that the server can choose to implement or not rather than something required since it is now being treated as a parameter. i also wonder if the driver should be required to get that setting right for it to work. it was different when there was bytecode. the user (and driver provider) had no control over these options, but this is different now under http.

> is the bulking feature optional for the server? it feels like it should be an optimization that the server can choose to implement or not rather than something required since it is now being treated as a parameter. i also wonder if the driver should be required to get that setting right for it to work. it was different when there was bytecode. the user (and driver provider) had no control over these options, but this is different now under http.

I changed implementation that the client can consume the server's results both in the form of `RemoteTraverser` and flat data.
So server can return any result from now, providers may decide what is better is there use cases.

> is it possible to fix or turn off invalid tests?

Yes, there is a flag to skip them. However, right now tests won't pass anyways because we are sending bytecode, and Docker isn't set up for it. I plan to remove bytecode next so we can re-enable all integration tests.

Hi @hugovk, Thanks for submitting this PR. Due to our branching structure, it would be best for this change to go into `3.6-dev` in order for the change to be incorporated in the existing 3.6.x and 3.7.x release lines, as well as future major releases.
Would you retargetting this PR to the `3.6-dev` branch?

> Do you still support Python 3.4? I don't think so, but couldn't find the min version documented. Well, this can be also removed if not:

Thanks for catching this. We do not support Python 3.4 anymore. Our current min version is python 3.8, however this will soon be raised to something more modern as 3.8 falls out of support.

Sure, coming up!

I didn't fully expect changing the base branch on the PR would work, but I'll rebase locally
Updated! Also removed the mock backport dependency, we can use the stdlib version instead.
Thank you for the update! VOTE +1

Thanks @hugovk, looks great! Just so you know, our process requires 3 approving votes and then we can merge the PR.
My vote is VOTE +1
